title: Personal Portfolio
description: This portfolio is built with Next.js, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. It showcases my projects, skills, and experience in a clean and modern design.

body.text: This portfolio is a showcase of my work and skills as a developer. It includes projects I've worked on, technologies I've used, and my experience in the field.

title: Garden Monorail
description: Who doesn't love a monorail?  This project is my attempt to make a 1:25 scale monorail which can run outdoors.

body.text: This is a rather new project in 2025.  I recently got a 3d printer which opens up a whole new world of possibilities.  I have always wanted a working monorail model, and sure Disney sells a small toy version, however that version has never been a "model", it's just a toy.

I found that there is a model of the Walt Disney World monorail on one of the 3d printing websites, so I'm starting there for prototyping.  I downloaded the model and first printed at O Scale, finding that not really the size I was thinking, I starting slicing and dicing to print at 1:22.5 scale.  I'm still torn between 1:22.5 or 1:25 or even maybe going down to 1:32.  But this is a start.

At the scale I want to build it at, I'll need to redraw virtually everything.  My plan is to have operational doors, reasonably accurate lighting and of course I have to make room for controls and batteries.
My son, Phillip, also happens to be a Pilot on the Walt Disney World Monorail, shown here with his proud mother (and my wife), Audra.

Galactic Scribble is a personal project with my family that combines our love for storytelling and product development. The project is ongoing and explores how I can create products and market through creative and emotional compelling stories.

I've been the point person with this venture, my wife Audra and daughter Piper have been helping with the the ideas and some of the AI art generation.  None of us are artists, I always say I can barely draw a stick figure, however with the developments in AI image generation, this opened up a new creative outlet for me.  I'm good at describing things in detail, and I can be fairly patient and persistant, so prompt engineering and tweaking is a large portion of this.

I do understand that artists and creatives have strong feeling about AI, and I respect their feelings, however I temper that with the reality that as being in software development for many years, no one seems to care that many of us developers, engineers and architects are also facing the same challenges.  Yet anytime I bring this up, they tell me I don't understand and can never understand.  They tell me the AI companies training on their art, and yes, that is true, and they also trained on every public github repo too, and they never asked either of our groups if that was OK.

My point is, whether or not Disney, Universal, Paramount win their lawsuits over training AI on their intellectual property, the reality is that AI is here to stay.  Those very companies are already using AI to assist with their technology, and they don't seem to care that it trained on other people's code.  Now one could argue there is a different component around copyright, and this may be true, it is also true that jobs will be lost by many sectors, not just creatives, and not just software development.

I view my use of AI for generating creative peices as augmentation to my skills and trying to adapt and stay near the front of the curve to give myself and my family an edge.  So far, we have learned that many people like our ideas, however we have not cracked the code of emotional story telling that gets them to open their wallets.

We don't have an advertising budget, so we rely on word of mouth and organic growth.  Over the past year, print on demand has gotten a lot more expensive yet consumers want to pay less and less.  As of June 2025 we turned off the store and are looking to rebrand and/or retool for a different product.

As shown above, our logo went from looking very IP (storm trooper) to something more just space man, but still having that retro feel.  In 2025 we decided to try pivoting to a new name Elemental Works Ltd.
My elemental works logos started in Illustrator and Adobe Stock for inspiration, then for the original I fed it back into AI for the pencil sketch effect.
My second Elemental works logo was designed to look like the old time porcelain signs you would see on the side of buildings advertising everything from oil to shaving cream.

Here is one of my last designs as of May 2025.  My Toad's Marvel's of the Motoring world expresses my love of Mr. Toads Wild Ride at Disneyland.  At first I wanted to use the term J. Thaddeus Toad, however that is a specifically a Disney name for him, so going back to the original story, yet still pushing the idea of a wild ride.  In my design, Mr Toad is now trying to get passing travellers to visit his museum of all things motoring.

Below is a gallery of some designs I made for this attempt at POD t-shirt direct to consumer sales website.  Many of these include some form of AI generation, though Hill Valley Fire Dept and the Tosche designs contains none, and the national parks only contain some as much as the background art, though this art was highly modified in Illustrator and/or photoshop to reduce color pallet, edit anything incorrect.  Most of these designs have tried to avoid direct copyright infringment.  Lucas, for instance never trademarked, or allowed the trademarks to lapse on most location names.  Using just the name does directly infringe on copyright.  Much of the Disney library of fairytales come from public domain, so I just had to find methods to make sure they are not directly tied to anything Disney.  I'd love to afford a Disney license for merchandise, however as a startup, that just isn't in the cards.

body.text: Many people think AI just produces ready for production art work on the first go.  Most of the concepts above took 6-8 hours minimum to make.  Brainstorming the ideas, then prompt engineering to get the right feel and tweaking, there are few of these designs that were less than 50 generations to get the base image we used.  Then converting to SVG and getting the right color pallete, layout, text and weathering.  If I were good at drawing and had a steady enough hand, this would all probably be a little faster.

title: Shopify Site Migration
description: Migrated Direct to Consumer (DTC) site from Magento 2 to Shopify, improving performance and reducing costs in under 30 days.

body.text: After being given the direction that we had to cut costs, the decision at the highest level was to replatform our DTC to Shopify.  I Migrated the site from Magento 2 to Shopify, improving performance and reducing costs in under 30 days.

items: Reduced cost of ownership
Improved page load
Higher internal user satisfaction
Setup 3rd party integrations for tracking, email, and reviews

title: Magento 2 Site Rescue
description: Rescue a Magento 2 site from a 3rd party agency relationship gone south.  Migrated to Adobe Commerce Cloud, improved performance, and ensured zero unplanned downtime.

body.text: After a 3rd party agency relationship went south, I was brought in to rescue the Magento 2 site. I migrated the site to Adobe Commerce Cloud, improved performance, and ensured zero unplanned downtime.

items: Migrated to Adobe Commerce Cloud
Improved performance with Fastly CDN
Removed unused code and partially completed project code from project
Removed some performance limited features installed by 3rd party
Ensured zero unplanned downtime
Monitored ongoing performance using New Relic
Results of migration and fixes have been zero unplanned downtime in over 2 years

title: Pumpkin Eyes
description: Building a pumpkin with animatronic eyes that follow you around the room.  The project is a fun exploration of hardware and software integration.

body.text: This project is a work in progress, progress is slow as other projects have gotten in the way.
I have printed 2 set of eyes and have hooked up the servos to an Arduino which also reads from an old game port joystick.
Based on EyeMech 1.0 by Will Cogley

items: Arduino Motion Control
Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision
OpenCV for Object Recognition

title: Magento to Acumatica ERP Connector
description: Developed a custom connector to sync orders and inventory between Magento and Acumatica ERP. The connector was built to handle high volume order processing and inventory management.

body.text: This project involved developing a custom connector to sync orders and inventory between Magento and Acumatica ERP. The connector was built to handle high volume order processing and inventory management.

After joinging Bandai Namco Collectibles, I found that the 3rd party who had made the existing sync had done so in a way that could only be described as the worst thing you could ever do.  The existing system not only made read and write directly to the DB without care or concern for best practices, but much of the processing happen when the user clicked the checkout button.  This resulted in times where the success page would never render if the remote ERP server was not available.

What I engineered was a system that unloaded most of the processing to a virtual machine running it's own independent set of services.  I made use of the newly added RabbitMQ feature of Magento 2 for both inventory and order sync.  Orders were written to a queue by Magento and then the service written in C# on the virtual machine would consume the orders, write those to Acumatica ERP via the API.  There were additional queue for messages from Acutmatica to Magento for orders updates, shipments, cancellations, inventory and several other functions.

After completion of this project the website was then able to handle a much higher volume of orders.  When I arrived, the site would generally crash with more than 3-5 people in active checkout.  Afterwords we were able to handle dozens of checkouts at a time.

title: Fraud Detection Tools
description: Developed a suite of tools to detect and prevent fraud in online transactions

body.text: NuMe USA was a business at high risk for fraud, sometimes several orders per day were potentially fraudulent and being able to flag those using the patterns we already knew was considered highly important, especially during the busy holiday season.  I developed a suite of tools to detect and prevent fraud in online transactions.  With these filters we were able to reduce chargebacks from several per month do to 1 a quarter.

Keep in mind this was before AI existed, so the tools were based on data analysis and pattern recognition us humans were doing.  The tools I built seem normal by today's processing standards.  Many of these filters I gladly shared during this time and have made it into such products and Bolt Checkout and Stripe.  I do not know if they indenpendently figured this stuff out, or if my conversations with industry leaders helped to push them in that direction.  Either way, it is just good to know how much the credit card gateways take this seriously today.
The filters I built included:

items: IP Address Filtering: Blocked known bad IP addresses and geolocations.
Email Address Filtering: Blocked known bad email addresses and domains.
Email Address filtering: Flag orders where the person's name is not part of the email address and when at least 1 other filter fails.
Velocity Checks: Flagged orders with multiple transactions from the same IP address or email address in a short period of time.
Shipping/Billing Address Checks: Flagged orders where the shipping address and billing address were different, or where the shipping address was a known bad address.
Phone Number: Flag orders with a known bad phone number, or where the phone number could never be reached.
Re-shippers: We had a lot of orders being shipped to what I call re-shippers. These addresses would be used to ship the product oversees.

body.text: I have continued to use the base filters at every location I've worked since creating them.  Though I re-write them everything for specific use case, they theory of them stays the same.  Stripe and other gateways do 99% of this today, however I still catch a few here and there.

title: Musical Theatre
description: My kids were in Muscial Theatre, and I helped with the technical side of the productions.

body.text: Sometime around 2010 my son decided to do musical theatre.  In Sonoma with had a local production company called Broadway Bound Kids.  As it happens, on of my classmates from highschool was the son of the organizers and also directed the shows, so I got into helping build the most magical sets and props for all the kids.

body.caption: King Triton's Spear, PVC pipe handle with plywood cutout, thing textures with sheetrock compound and painted and aged.  My wife Audra holding it for approval photo sent to the director.
I made a quick ships wheel since no one could find the proper one in storage for this show.

I think this is one of my favorite lightweight backdrops I made.  It is munchkin land from the Wizard of Oz before being painted.  Most of our moving set peices are made from door skins and framed with furring stips.  High school kids had to be able to move this set peice on off stage 3-4 times per day for 2 weeks of practice and shows.
One of several curved doors I made over the years.  This was used in Hairspray when she jumps out of the can.  You can see the bottom of the hairspray can in the background.
This dome is the top to a can of Hairspray.

body.text: There were 14 shows over 7 years, I never took a lot of pictures, as I find more of the finished work I start posting them here.

title: South Napa Earthquake Recovery
description: The South Napa Earthquake turned into an 3 year recovery project to move and rebuild the entire manufacturing facility.

body.text: South Napa Earthquake Recovery

On August 24, 2014, the South Napa Earthquake struck at 3:20 AM with a magnitude of 6.0. The earthquake caused significant damage to many buildings in the area, including the Western Dovetail factory. The building was red tagged and we would never return to make drawers there again.

The wood Jointers shop on Mare Island was originally built around 1904. The story has it that in 1906, the great San Francisco earthquake also badly damaged the brick on the building, and the Navy put it back up just the way it was, only to fall back down 100 years later.

body.caption: Rear upstairs window fallen in
Broken water pipe between Jointers Shop and Sawmill.

body.text: Being in the position of a 'non-producer' — I didn’t make product that needed to be shipped to customers — I became the lead in the recovery effort.
We spent a few months working in borrowed space from 2 or 3 other companies on Mare Island. Thank you to Dimensions Unlimited and Battle Bots for letting us barge in and saving our bacon.

We secured a new space only a few hundred yards away, but were only allowed into the old building 2 days per week, 4 hours at a time, with a max of 4 people. Everything had to be choreographed — people, tools, equipment — so we touched only what we needed.

body.caption: Inside the old shop before the earthquake.

Thanks to some neighbors with a big lift, we were able to move the 3 head 53" width belt sander to the new building in one afternoon. For this move, we had to disconnect and jack it up high enough to fit the forks on the previous time allotted to go into the building, so all in all moving this just 400 yards took close to 2 weeks.
The neighbors were not available for this move, so we made it work with what we had. Lift up, back in the truck, set it down and drive out.

body.text: The new space just down the road. What’s hard to see is the earthquake also damaged this building. It would be almost 3 months before we were allowed in the back 40 feet as that upper part of the wall had separated from the lower concrete portion.
This project was many projects in itself. I am only going to show a small snippet of everything I did, and only the things I was the lead on, or in most cases, the only person working on.

The new building had pneumatic operated louvers on the roof, switched with solenoid valves and relays. Since much of the other air handling equipment had been removed, I had to troubleshoot the existing system and augment with my own ideas.

For this project I first hooked up push buttons to open and close them, then built a parallel relay array and used an off-the-shelf 120 volt ethernet power switch to control them from the shop floor computers.

body.caption: Roof vent diagram
Pneumatic Valve Array
Manual Control
Relays
Web Power Switch

body.text: There were a lot of moving pieces and a lot of supplies required during the build of the new shop, and all this was done while our production continued in the same space. Machines were temporarily hooked up with flexible cables and covered to make sure trip hazards were minimal.

I built this cabinet and drawers early on to hold all the nuts, bolts, electrical connectors, and other supplies I needed in the space over the next 18 months. You can see one of the shop touchscreen terminals above which allowed checking and updating job schedules along with operating vents, heaters, fans and lighting.
Most of what you see is temporary setup. I would work from 5pm until midnight or later to move and permanently install the equipment so it could be ready for the next day.

Hiring an electrician was not in the budget, so I bought a copy of the National and California Electrical code and started drawing plans for the new shop. I had to figure out how to wire the new space, and how to get power to all the machines, lights, and outlets. Our supply voltage in the new space was 480 volt 3 phase and the old shop was 240 volt, so I had to calculate all the loads and spec out the transformers we would need.
There was a lot of conduit to bend, from 3/4" all the way up to 2"

I built these supports to carry the conduit and air lines out of new pallet rack endframe and double sided unistrut. Along the way I had to calculate the load and show that the weight of the planned conduit, wire and air lines were within the acceptable load capacity of the unistrut spans.

Dust Collection had to be re-engineered and reinstalled as well. The old shop used the building's original 24" dust collector installed by the Navy. We had to scrounge whatever dust collectors we could find for cheap and install them machine by machine.
Code compliance also meant labeling everything properly.

body.caption: Breakers
More Breakers
Exit signs with braille as well. Each sign researched, ordered and installed.

body.text: The things which didn't get photos taken.

items: Office Move x2, x3? We moved our office several times, at first into a neighbor, then to a converter house, then to the new office in the same building as the shop.
Plumbing: Mostly pneumatics, some copper pipe soldering, and a lot of fexible hose connections.
Rigging & Moving: Not only did we move our shop, but we also had to move our storage building, another 12,000 square feet of space and all the high bay racking.
Construction: I had to build new walls in the office, plus a soundproof room for the server rack.
Fiber: We scrounged some of the original Fiber Optic cable from the Navy in the new shop that was no longer used and re-routed between our new office on the far side of the building from the shop.
Project Management: I had to manage the entire project from start to finish, including budgeting, scheduling, and coordinating with all the stakeholders.
Safety: I had to ensure that all work was done safely and in compliance with OSHA regulations.
Structured Cabling: Many thousands of feet of Cat6 cable were run throughout the new shop and office.
Wifi: For our temporary setups we were in 4 places.  I hooked up point to point wifi between the buildings in order to keep everyone connected.  We were even able to run IP phones between locations.

title: Tradeshows
description: We went to a lot of trade shows, I spent a lot of time making them go smoothly.

body.text: Not long after starting at Western Dovetail I starting helping with Tradeshows.  Thanks to the owner Max Hunter, I was able to go to many of these shows, and for quite a few of them I was the point person to gather everything we needed, make sure it all got shipped and arrived on time.

I can not take credit for building the show buildings such as the bar and other shops, and the clock was built by Max's father George.  Most of the other displays I had some hand in, whether I built it myself, or in partnership with Max and Victor (our shop foreman.)

body.caption: I think this was the last show I attended in 2017, AWFS Las Vegas.  This show was our first time with touch screens for guests to interact with.
This was IWF Atlanta in 2006.  My first visit to Atlanta, GA
Setup IWF 2006 in Atlanta, GA

This was our largest booth space ever, I think either 40x40.  My wife Audra helped setup since Max and Josh were delayed until the night before opening.  Also thanks to our neighboring vendor Blum for lending a couple guys with ladders to help us get the bar vertical this year.
More of that big booth space at AWFS.
Inside those building is where we kept the give-aways.  We were known to give away these sample drawers that happen to function as an inbox for your desk.
I believe this was IWF in 2016?

title: Dovetails!
description: Various projects with dovetails and woodworking while working at Western Dovetail.

body.text: Thoughout my years at Western Dovetail, I worked on many projects in the shop.  This project is a gallery of things I had a lot to do with, much of this I was wholey responsible for.

body.caption: 180 degree Laminated Drawer Fronts and shallower Carved Drawer Fronts.
Nested Tables with Dovetail Joinery, some of the thickest and largest dovetails I made.
These Large Box Joints were cut by Max Hunter, however my part in this was Milling the wood and sanding and finishing.
I made these samples so that we could show of new capablities of a machine we recently purchased.
Close look and the custom dovetail spaceing and depth.

This Vertical Grain Fir cabinet was my first fully 3d design.  Everything was designed in AutoCAD and then cut sheet made and then work began.  Myself and 1 other shop employee built the entire cabinet for this display.
The first ever Dovetail Corner drawer was made by Max, Victor, and Myself.  There was quite a bit of trial and error.
Closeup of the front of the Corner Drawer.
We had quite a few designed for trash bin drawers.  I can't be sure I made this particular one for our display, however I did make several different versions of these.

title: Magic Box
description: The magic box is a spectacle of wooden boxes that rise from within themselves to show all the different joinery we could do.  The project was a collaboration with the owner of Western Dovetail.

body.text: In 2009 the owner of Western Dovetail and I created a spectacle of wooden boxes.  I had created a small stack of 4 dovetail boxes on a new machine that we had just acquired which fit inside each other, just as a desk novelty to show how small it would go.  Little did I know that we would make a tower which would rise from within itself to show all the different joinery we could do.

For the most part, I made all the boxes from picking and milling the wood to dovetailing, sanding, and finishing.  we tried to find a lift method for several weeks, penciling out several ideas until with landing on something called a Zip Chain Actuator.  The US representative for the company only had 1 demo unit, and that units gear box was 3d printed, which after 2 years of use was worn out and we were able to get a machined replacement unit.

The actuator was powered with a 12 volt motor and Allen Bradely relays and timers along with an off the shelf 4 channel car alarm/door remote.  I drew up the logic and wired the display while Max figured out how to attached all the boxes and support the fully extended towel.

body.caption: AWFS 2009 Magic Box fully extended

items: Dovetail Joinery
Zip Chain Actuator
Relay Logic Control

body.text: Zip Chain Actuator

title: Milling Logs
description: My brother and I milling an Ash log into lumber.  We both grew up with the woodworking gene, our father was a shop teacher for many years and even built the house we grew up in.  We continue the family tradtion of getting outside and making things ourselves.

body.text: In 2015, my brother Charlie and I milled some Ash he got from a local tree company. We had a lot of fun milling it, and we both made a few projects with the wood, Charlie made a table top he used in his dining room for several years and I have still got a couple think slabs waiting for a project.

body.title: Timelapse of the first pass include ripping and initial planing.

title: Timelapse Panorama
description: As the dry docks at Mare Island were being re-opened, our shop had a front row seat to the action.  I setup a point and tilt camera which would take a set of picutre each minite.

body.text: This timelapse was created using a foscam point and tilt camera pointed out of the windows on the mezzanine of building 118 on Mare Island.  I had a process which would take a set of 3 pictures, moving the camera between each frame.  Then using Hugin to stich them together and ImageMagfic for some cropping.  I later used ffmpeg to combine the images into a timelapse

body.title: Timelapse of the Morgan Fire on Mount Diablo September 8th, 2013

body.text: Hugin panorama photo stitcher
ImageMagick
FFmpeg

We were eventually asked to take down our camera as it became a problem to the dry dock operations.  We had caught Mythbusters filming a segment with buster, and then when they started tearing apart the mothball fleet, various people who didn't like what they were doing started using it to report on the goings on.  We support local jobs and didn't want to get into the politcs, so that ended the fun experiment.

title: Railroad Photography
description: As long as I can remember I have been facinated with railroads.  I have been taking pictures of trains since I was a kid, and I still do it today.

body.text: Much of what I'll show in this project is 35mm photos I took in the 1990s; I still shoot 35mm film today and develop myself at home.

body.caption: Union Pacific Emerging from Tunnel and accross the Keddie Wye Bridge
Engineer Mark operated the California Northern special passenger train from Vallejo to Santa Rosa with various dignitaries on board.

body.caption: Southern Pacific 8307 heading east in Suisun, CA, and SD40T-2 showing the typical amount of weathering SP was know for.
This passenger coach, named the Lady Gaye Laurel, LGLX 3343, sitting in Schellville, CA around 1993 or 1994.

body.caption: California Northern 105 at Anheuser-Busch in Suisun, CA

body.caption: California Northern 113 in the yard at American Canyon, CA.  Always been sad how much I allowed this negative to get scratched early on.

body.alt: Sign at Ozol - Yard near Martinez, CA
body.caption: Sign at Ozol - Yard near Martinez, CA

Amtrak 347 San Pablo, CA.  In the background you can just see the UPS intermodel yard.  Amtrak is here on the old Southern Pacfic Line, the UPS yard is on the old Santa Fe line only 100 yards apart in this location.
